title: As Jeff Sessions mulls Alabama Senate run, some campaigns stress loyalty to Trump
text:
CLOSE Former U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions reflects on his time in the Trump administration as he speaks during the Montgomery Area Chamber of Commerce annual meeting in Montgomery, Ala. Montgomery Advertiser

MONTGOMERY — If former Sen. Jeff Sessions gets into the Alabama Senate race, the Republicans already in the race say they’ll stick to their plans.

But many of those plans include pledges of loyalty to President Donald Trump. And some seemed likely to weaponize Sessions' time as U.S. attorney general under Trump, a brief affair that ended bitterly.

“If the voters of Alabama want a career politician as their next U.S. senator, then they have plenty of choices,” a statement from former Auburn head coach Tommy Tuberville’s campaign said Tuesday. “If they want a political outsider who will actually stand with President Trump and fight the DC establishment when it matters the most, then I am the only choice. Jeff Sessions had a chance to stand and defend the President and he failed.”

Former U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions speaks during the Montgomery Area Chamber of Commerce annual meeting in Montgomery, Ala., on Tuesday, Dec. 11, 2018. (Photo: Jake Crandall/ Advertiser)

There was a spectrum of opinion Tuesday on the likelihood of Sessions — a U.S. senator from Alabama from 1997 to 2017 — entering the race. Staffers on three separate campaigns suggested Sessions’ entry would hurt campaigns other than their own. But few thought the messages of the campaigns would change.

The Associated Press and Politico reported Monday evening that Sessions was looking into the possibility of entering the race, citing three Republicans with knowledge of the situation. Qualifying for the March 3 primary ends on Nov. 8.

After winning election in 1996, Sessions cruised to three re-elections while firmly positioning himself on the right edge of the Republican Party. He became notable as a hardliner on immigration policies.

Former Auburn coach Tommy Tuberville speaking at Montgomery Quarterback Club on Sept. 12, 2017 (Photo: Michael Galvin)

Sessions was an early endorser of Trump’s presidential campaign in 2016 and was later named his attorney general, where he aggressively used the courts for immigration enforcement and restricted asylum access.

Sessions recused himself from the investigation into the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia due to meetings he had with Russian ambassador Sergei Kislyak, which he did not disclose during his confirmation hearing in 2017. The recusal led to hot-tempered criticism from the president, who belittled his decision and later called his hiring of Sessions his “biggest mistake.”

Despite the criticism, Sessions has continued to praise the president in the few public appearances he has made since stepping down late last year.

“This very public adventure, I have to say, exceeded my expectations,” Sessions said at an appearance in Montgomery in December 2018. “I’m proud of Trump’s policy agenda and proud to have a part in it.”

Similar loyalty to Trump is a hallmark of the Republicans in the race. U.S. Rep. Bradley Byrne, R-Mobile, has been a vocal critic of the impeachment investigation, probing Trump's conditioning military aid to Ukraine on officials there providing information embarrassing to former Vice President Joe Biden, a presidential candidate. Byrne also voted against a resolution criticism Trump’s decision to withdraw combat troops from northern Syria.

Lenze Morris, a spokeswoman for Byrne, said in a statement Tuesday that “Bradley isn’t going anywhere.”

“He is laser-focused on becoming the next senator from Alabama and will lead efforts to secure our borders, fight for American workers and stand up to Democrats and their deep state allies attempting to nullify and sabotage the Trump presidency.”

U.S. Rep Bradley Byrne looks at the slavery statues during a congressional delegation visit at the EJI National Memorial in Montgomery, Ala., on Friday, March 1, 2019. (Photo: Jake Crandall/ Advertiser)

It’s not at all certain how Trump’s criticisms of Sessions would play out in the primary, in part because Trump’s endorsement record in Alabama GOP primaries is mixed. He gave his blessing to U.S. Rep. Martha Roby, R-Montgomery, in 2018 in a crowded primary where Roby’s opponents tried to make an issue of her criticism of Trump bragging about grabbing women’s genitals on an Access Hollywood tape released in 2016. Roby ultimately prevailed in a runoff.

But Trump’s endorsement of then-Sen. Luther Strange in a special election in 2017 failed to boost the incumbent, who lost a special election to former Alabama Chief Justice Roy Moore. Despite accusations of Moore assaulting, harassing, or making unwelcome comments to nine separate women, Trump later endorsed Moore, who lost the general election to Democratic nominee Doug Jones.

Moore, who is running again for the seat, said in a statement Tuesday Sessions entering the race would have no bearing on his campaign.

“I like Jeff Sessions, I know him,” the statement said. “It’s up to him. It wouldn’t affect one way or another what I do.”

More: Doug Jones leads third-quarter fundraising in U.S. Senate race

The prospect of an impeachment vote in the Senate is potentially complicating an already tough election fight for Doug Jones, a red-state Democrat. (Photo: Kim Chandler, AP)

Jones is considered one of the Senate’s more vulnerable incumbents, thanks to Trump’s all-but-certain presence on the presidential ballot next year and straight-ticket Republican voting. But the incumbent has held his own in the money chase: He pulled in $2 million in the third quarter, more than the entire GOP field combined, and has $5 million on hand. Byrne has $2.5 million on hand and Tuberville has $1.4 million in the bank.

The Friends of Sessions Senate Committee reported $2.4 million on hand in its latest FEC filing, filed earlier this month.
